Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Medium: Collaborative Research: Neural Control of Powered Artificial Legs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent breakthroughs in the mechatronics of powered lower limb (LL) prostheses hold the promise of enabling restoration for the large and growing population of lower limb amputees of a broad spectrum of functionality (e.g., standing up when seated in a chair, climbing stairs, and even running). The PIs argue that to realize this potential it is essential to provide neural control of artificial legs. The application of existing upper limb (UL) neural control approaches is inappropriate to this end, because the UL and LL neural control mechanisms are significantly different. In particular, most activities involving the lower limbs recruit both involuntary (spinal cord) and voluntary (supra-spinal) neural control, present high dynamics, and require multi-joint coordination and control of unstable locomotion, characteristics which combine to make the design specifications for neural control of LL prostheses much more demanding than those for UL devices. In this project the PIs will address this challenge by developing an innovative neural control system for powered artificial legs that can recognize and exploit multi-scale user intent (e.g., general motor commands such as intended task vs. detailed motor commands such as intended joint motion) to modulate intrinsic (autonomous) control of multiple LL prosthetic joints for locomotor and nonlocomotor task performance. The goals are to support reverse-engineering of the neural control of human locomotion while creating innovative neural-machine interfacing (NMI) technology that enables users to control the dynamics of LL prostheses in a natural, adaptive and flexible way. Inspired by what is currently known about the neurological organization and function of the human motor control system, the PIs' approach is to design a novel NMI based on a combination of noninvasive scalp electroencephalography (EEG) and surface electromyography (EMG). The hypothesis is that fusion of low-level peripheral and high-level central neural control sources can achieve multi-scale user intent recognition with higher accuracy and more rapid response time than can be realized with either EEG or EMG alone. A hierarchical control scheme for powered LL prostheses, in which multi-scale user intent identified by the NMI modulates intrinsic (autonomous) control, will support intuitive and efficient prosthesis use in dynamic, multi-joint coordinated movements while significantly reducing the mental burden of the prosthesis user in locomotion because the cyclic motion is achieved autonomously (this is desired because we rarely think about knee and ankle control when walking). The PIs will also explore correlation across EEG and EMG signals, which may provide insight into neural adaption and the time course of cortical control during the initiation and generation of gait, including how the brain initiates walking and regulates motor output in anticipation of key events such as foot placement at landing or during stepping up and down, weight acceptance, and push-off into swing phase. Finally, the PIs will use translational research to validate their novel approach in patients with trans-femoral amputations (a high and challenging amputation level).

Broader Impacts: The PIs' long-term objective is to develop true bionic prostheses that feel and work just like real legs. Their approach in this project represents a paradigm shift in the control of lower limb wearable prosthetics. As such, project outcomes will directly impact both the Human-Robot Interaction and Brain-Machine Interface research communities. The findings will also be relevant to the neuroscience and rehabilitation communities, in that they will help elucidate the adaptive spinal cord and cortical contributions to human locomotion, while providing innovative and functional neuro-prosthetics solutions to improve the lives of lower limb amputees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the United States, there are approximately 2 million people living with limb loss. Lower limb (LL) amputations are much more frequent than upper limb amputations. Moreover, according to some estimates, recent combat operations overseas had resulted in over 1900 service men and women with LL amputations from 2001 to 2017. Lower limb amputation is one of the major causes of disability. The mobility, stability, and ability to perform basic activities of daily living (ADLs) are significantly impacted in people with leg amputations, and thus, these amputees depend on assistive devices, such as artificial legs, to regain these lost functions. Therefore, there is a significant need for advancing the technologies in leg prostheses because the affected population is large and growing, and the function of current available leg prostheses is still limited due to the lack of an intuitive and flexible user control interface that can work in changing environments.

The major goal of this collaborative project was to create and evaluate a novel, multimodal (hybrid) neural machine interface (NMI) for powered lower limb (LL) prostheses to solve the problem of inadequate integration between lower limb wearable robots and their users. The goal was to develop LL neuroprostheses that interface with both the central (CNS) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS) to restore lost motor capabilities to people with limb loss. To achieve this goal, we recorded brain waves from the CNS using noninvasive electroencephalography (EEG) and PNS signals from the amputee users' residual limb using electromyography (EMG). By combining these two types of central and peripheral neural signals, it was expected that the performance and reliability of our new NMI would outperform existing NMIs that only used one type of neural signal. Moreover, analysis of these signals will inform how the brain and the body control real and artificial legs.

This project was a joint effort between a research team from the University of Houston (UH) with expertise in EEG-based neuroprostheses and a research team at North Carolina State University (NCSU) with expertise in EMG-based neuroprostheses. Each research team explored the two different types of neural signals independently and supported the other team in their related efforts. Moreover, the NCSU team fabricated a simplified version of their prosthetic leg that was used by the UH team as a test bed for validation.

Scientific Merit of the Project: A major intellectual contribution of the UH team was the identification of EEG brain patterns and EMG muscle activation patterns of lower limb movements in locomotion and non-locomotion (e.g., sitting and standing) tasks in people with LL amputations via EEG and EMG recordings. Specifically, we used EEG data collected during multi-terrain walking to identify the neural correlates of walking during the transition from level ground to stairs.  Our results revealed significant changes in brain waves prior to the transition between terrains in several cortical areas. The UH team also developed a hierarchical controller for powered LL prostheses that combines EEG and EMG fusion based NMI and intrinsic (autonomous) prosthesis control. To achieve this aim, EEG and EMG decoders were designed to infer movement intention from the users. The UH team also explored the neural representation of the phantom limb after amputation occurs using structural and functional magnetic resonance imaging (MRI/fMRI), which provide high spatial resolution complementary to the high-temporal resolution afforded by EEG. Our results suggest that the phantom limb appears to be represented by the original representation of the limb in the cortex, even after amputation occurs.

Broader Impact of the Project:  The outcomes of this project are significant in that they 1) inform the design of future bionic prostheses that feel and work as the real legs to improve the quality of life of people with lower limb amputations; 2) provided new fundamental knowledge and advanced understanding of the neural representations for walking; 3) contributed to the career development and education of a new generation of neuroengineers by mentoring and training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students, as well as high-school students; 4) contributed to the scientific community through data sharing and publication of ten peer-reviewed journal and conference papers; and 5) contributed to science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) outreach through technical demonstrations of robotic and EEG-based neuroprostheses to undergraduates, K-12 students and teachers, and institutions at the Texas Medical Center in Houston.
